I am not a professional photographer--just a grandma that likes to take LOTS of pictures of her fast-moving 3 year old granddaughter! And that was the first problem I encountered. In half of my photos she is a blur. The background is clear, but she isn't. If she is sitting still, I can get a great picture. But if she so much as moves a hand, then that hand is a blur. The second issue has to do with processing speed. I frequently like to take several pictures in a row--click, click, click. My old Kodak could do that, but my new powershot can not. It takes a good 4 seconds between shots to process and get ready again. I know that may sound fast, but it's not, really. A lot can happen in 4 seconds, especially with kids! And the last of my complaints--the camera kept blinking the "shaky camera" icon at me, meaning I wasn't holding the camera steady. I've never had trouble with that before. My pictures were never blurry, nor did I shake when using the Kodak.All that being said, the camera does take very good pictures when the subject is unmoving and it is easy to use. It is very lightweight, but does have a cheap plasticky feel to it.I am returning the camera and hunting for another Kodak!

Reviews.Title: Very nice for our needs
Reviews.Author: Alyunya422
Reviews.Content: Very nice light camera with good zoom and veryt nice picture quality. The only issue I have with it is that I boutght it of my in-laws and not only they, but even I are confused in the symbols on the botton because they are small and the meaning is not always clear

Reviews.Title: Excelente producto!
Reviews.Author: JOSE AGUIAR
Reviews.Content: Satisfecho, buen producto para todo consumidor de cámaras digitales de clase baja/media diría yo. Un gusto con tantas fotografías que he tomado.

Reviews.Title: Arrived malfunctioning; no support
Reviews.Author: J. Timothy Kern "geriatric rocket rider"
Reviews.Content: Received A3000IS as a gift, unopened. Looked cute; probably would make a good backup/pocket cam. So I charged up the battery and read the manual. Images would show on the viewfinder, but the camera wouldn't take pictures. Tried online help -- yup, it's wrong. Tried phone support -- yup, it's not working. Got an RMA number and sent it in -- and got an estimate for a $92 flat-rate repair!Called and explained I didn't have the original shipping info. (It was a gift, and we're not talking any more. TMI.) I asked if they'd run the serial number to see if it had been manufactured within the past year. At least that would tell us whether it's under a year old! Couldn't/wouldn't do that. They just sent another estimate.Now, refurb cameras (what they'd send me if I paid $92 for a "repair") are selling for $69, and new cameras are going for $95 -- and Canon wants me to send them $92 for an out-of-warranty exchange. THE CAMERA DIDN't WORK RIGHT OUT OF THE BOX. IT's A NEW CAMERA.I've been shooting Canon since the 1970s, sometimes professionally. Never again.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA AT A GREAT PRICE
Reviews.Author: LASTCALL
Reviews.Content: AT $71 THIS IS A GREAT CAMERA WITH CASE AND A 4 GIG SDHC CARD.  PICTURES JUST AS GOOD AS MY $700 NIKON D50

Reviews.Title: Great little P&S; with one caveat
Reviews.Author: Todd
Reviews.Content: I really like this little inexpensive P&S; camera. At it's price point, it's not likely to be beaten in feaures, or lens quality. I keep trying out these inexpensive Canon P&S; cameras, and they're typically terrific save for one flaw.The one flaw that they all seem to suffer from(even the later models with the Digic IV processor) is the inablility to deal with lots of material in the red part of the spectrum. I should note that I'm not a professional, but a relatively serious amateur that has pretty high standards for even the least expensive P&S.;The oversaturation of complex reds in a scene(I use a particular spot in my flower garden to test for resolution of this admittedly hard to deal with subject) shows the camera's limitations. The reds are not so oversaturated that the subject loses all definition, but the reds do lose a lot of sharpness. I should note that macro shots of individual flowers are very sharp and there is little color shifting. They are also resolved to an unexpectedly high degree.Battery life with the Li-ion battery is reasonable. Some people will dismiss this camera because of the proprietary Li-ion battery, but not me. Rechargeable batteries with included charger at this price point are really a plus.Since I'm comparing this camera to other sub xxx dollar cameras, it doesn't warrant removing a star for it's inability to resolve a very complex scene with five different - and brilliantly colored - shades in the red part of the spectrum. No camera(Canon or otherwise) around this price point - and many that are multiples of the cost of the A3000IS - I have tried have a roughly equally difficult time with this scene.In summation, it doesn't get much, if any, better than this for your money spent. I'm hopeful that in time, as the pixel wars die, and that CMOS sensors migrate into the bottom of manufacturer's lines, things will likely change, but for now..this little P&S; is a quite competent camera at a bargain price. Oh, and the video isn't bad either ;)

Reviews.Author: K. Abozeeter
Reviews.Content: Got this as a gift for my dad.  He's been using it for 3 months and has no complaints.  Probably takes 150 photos a month and uses all of the auto settings.

Reviews.Title: Pleased

Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my recent trip to Italy.  I wanted something small and light weight.  It worked well.  I should have taken more time prior to the trip to get to know more about it.  I took over 464 pictures.  I was surprised that the battery needed to be charged more often than I had expected.  Luckily I took the charger  and the converter with me

Reviews.Content: I loved the camera, but it is impossible to get the battery back in.  Canon put an plastic piece of crap to hold the battery in an fit is almost impossible (currently impossible, I can't get it in) to get the battery back in.Don't buy this until they have a decent battery clip. Reviews.Title: First Digi Camera
Reviews.Author: bobhc2 "bob"
Reviews.Content: First time user learning how to operate camera needing to learn more about red eye!  Otherwise so far so good!

Reviews.Title: Terrible picture quality
Reviews.Author: Mum to 3 boys
Reviews.Content: I know how to shoot pictures.  I am not expecting the quality of these pics to be equal with what I would get on my DSLR, but I did expect them to be better than my Blackberry.  The images are not clear, and many of them are a blur thanks to the shutter speed.There are many wonderful reviews on this camera, but I have seen much better photographs from many other lower end point and shoots.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing
Reviews.Author: dom085
Reviews.Content: Pictures were terribly noisy, camera seems to rely heavily on high ISO's to take a picture. Couldn't stand the graininess, looks like photos are printed on sandpaper.The lousy thing focuses worse than a kid with ADD, and takes forever to do so. I would hold the shutter halfway down holding the camera as still as a corpse, and it would still take 5 seconds before it satisfied itself with faint blobs of color and beep as if it was ready for Ansel Adams to come over and take his masterpiece. THERE WAS NO REASON IT COULDN'T FOCUS. This pos has cataracts, I swear.Cheap feel to the body. The edges weren't aligned nicely, and chintzy plastic body had unfinished edges. It feels like holding one of those disposable digital cameras with Hannah Montana on it or something that they give away free when you buy a foil balloon or some crap. It probably floats in water.I foolishly rushed in to buy it since it was marked from somewhere in the $200's down to $99. It's not even worth that.I would consider keeping it if I found one on the sidewalk, but only if the trash can was too far away.

Reviews.Title: Okay for the price but not a keeper.
Reviews.Author: HappyME
Reviews.Content: This is a rather nice little point-and-shoot and an decent value. BUT! There just is no excuse for not having a view finder. I know the low end p&s; cameras don't any more but they should. I found I could adjust to shooting indoors and in high definition settings. But outdoors with a nondescript background, I can't find my subject. It's hit or miss on getting those shots and I hate that.I do like the image stabilization and lithium battery. My previous camera for this application took super shots and had excellent image stabilization. But it was an "A" model that required AA batteries. Not only was it heavy but it was constantly "hungry".I would keep this except that even being a good deal, it's money I feel I've wasted. If I can't use the camera for all-around casual work, it's just not a bargain at all.If, at some point, I can afford a small Canon camera that does have a view finder, I'll certainly take a close look. Meanwhile, I'll stick with my A570 and lesson learned.
